dialogs.original: Well met; good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.
dialogs.translated: Right on time. Good day, Titus and Hortensius.

dialogs.original: The like to you kind Varro.
dialogs.translated: And you as well.

dialogs.original: Lucius!What, do we meet together?
dialogs.translated: Oh, a representative of Lucius! Are you here to see Timon as well?

dialogs.original: Ay, and I thinkOne business does command us all; for mine Is money.
dialogs.translated: Yes. We do all have the same goal, and mine is money.

dialogs.original: So is theirs and ours.
dialogs.translated: And your goal is our goal.

dialogs.original: Lucius' Servant And Sir Philotus too!
dialogs.translated: Not only Lucius's Servant, but Philotus's too!

dialogs.original: Good day at once.
dialogs.translated: Good day.

dialogs.original: Welcome, good brother.What do you think the hour?
dialogs.translated: Hello. What time is it?

dialogs.original: Labouring for nine.
dialogs.translated: Close to nine.

dialogs.original: So much?
dialogs.translated: That late?

dialogs.original: Is not my lord seen yet?
dialogs.translated: Has anyone seen Timon yet?

dialogs.original: Not yet.
dialogs.translated: Not yet.

dialogs.original: I wonder on't; he was wont to shine at seven.
dialogs.translated: I wonder why. He usually wakes up at seven.

dialogs.original: Ay, but the days are wax'd shorter with him:    You must consider that a prodigal course    Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable.    I fear 'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse;    That is one may reach deep enough, and yet    Find little.
dialogs.translated: Yeah, but the days have become shorter for him, because you should remember that the path of extravagance descends like the sun in winter, even if it does not regain its height the following year. And I'm afraid that Lord Timon's estate is withering, no matter how hard he tries to recover money.

dialogs.original: I am of your fear for that.
dialogs.translated: Me too.

dialogs.original: I'll show you how to observe a strange event.Your lord sends now for money.
dialogs.translated: And I'll tell you something funny. [To HORTENSIUS] Your lord sent you to get money, right?

dialogs.original: Most true, he does.
dialogs.translated: Yes.

dialogs.original: And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift,For which I wait for money.
dialogs.translated: And he now possesses jewels from Timon, which I lent him the money to buy.

dialogs.original: It is against my heart.
dialogs.translated: Unfortunately, yes.

dialogs.original: Mark, how strange it shows,    Timon in this should pay more than he owes:    And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels,    And send for money for 'em.
dialogs.translated: It's so weird how Timon must pay out more than he owes, while your lord seems to get the privilege of wearing the jewels and getting to request the money paid for them.

dialogs.original: I'm weary of this charge, the gods can witness:I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth,And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.
dialogs.translated: God I'm sick of this job. I know that my lord spent Timon's money and now in his ingratitude is as bad as a thief.

dialogs.original: Yes, mine's three thousand crowns: what's yours?
dialogs.translated: Yeah. My lord is asking for three thousand crowns. What about yours?

dialogs.original: Five thousand mine.
dialogs.translated: Five thousand.

dialogs.original: 'Tis much deep: and it should seem by the sun,Your master's confidence was above mine;Else, surely, his had equall'd.
dialogs.translated: Way too much. It seems your master is more brazen even than mine, otherwise mine would have asked for as much.

dialogs.original: One of Lord Timon's men.
dialogs.translated: One of Timon's servants is coming

dialogs.original: Flaminius! Sir, a word: pray, is my lord ready tocome forth?
dialogs.translated: Flaminius! Can we talk for a second? Is Timon coming?

dialogs.original: No, indeed, he is not.
dialogs.translated: No he's not.

dialogs.original: We attend his lordship; pray, signify so much.
dialogs.translated: At least tell him we are waiting for him.

dialogs.original: I need not tell him that; he knows you are too diligent.
dialogs.translated: I don't have to do that. He knows how attentive you are.

dialogs.original: Ha! is not that his steward muffled so?He goes away in a cloud: call him, call him.
dialogs.translated: Ha! Is that his assistant wrapped up like that? Get him, he's trying to sneak away under cover.

dialogs.original: Do you hear, sir?
dialogs.translated: [Pestering FLAVIUS] Can we talk, please?

dialogs.original: By your leave, sir,
dialogs.translated: [Pestering FLAVIUS] Please, sir

dialogs.original: What do ye ask of me, my friend?
dialogs.translated: What do you want?

dialogs.original: We wait for certain money here, sir.
dialogs.translated: We want the money Timon owes.

dialogs.original: Ay,    If money were as certain as your waiting,    'Twere sure enough.    Why then preferr'd you not your sums and bills,    When your false masters eat of my lord's meat?    Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts    And take down the interest into their    gluttonous maws.    You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up;    Let me pass quietly:    Believe 't, my lord and I have made an end;    I have no more to reckon, he to spend.
dialogs.translated: Yes, if only money were as sure a thing as you all asking for it, then you would definitely have it. Why didn't your masters send you to pay the bills for the food they ate off Timon's plate? That way, they could smile and enjoy the debts he incurred and then shovel all the interest he owed into their greedy mouths. You're not doing yourself any favors riling me up like this. Let me go. My lord and I have parted ways. I have no more counsel to give, and he has no more money to spend.

dialogs.original: Ay, but this answer will not serve.
dialogs.translated: Yes, but that still isn't enough.

dialogs.original: If 'twill not serve,'tis not so base as you;For you serve knaves.
dialogs.translated: If it's not enough, it's still worth more than all of you, because you serve bad men.

dialogs.original: How! what does his cashiered worship mutter?
dialogs.translated: What did the fired man just say?

dialogs.original: No matter what; he's poor, and that's revenge    enough.   Who can speak broader than he that has no    house to put his head in? such may rail against    great buildings.
dialogs.translated: Whatever, he's poor and that's punishment enough for him. After all, who can say whatever he wants more than the man with no home and nothing to lose?

dialogs.original: O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.
dialogs.translated: Here is Servilius. Now we'll know what is going on.

dialogs.original: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some    other hour, I should derive much from't;   for,    take't of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to    discontent: his comfortable temper has forsook him;    he's much out of health, and keeps his chamber.
dialogs.translated: If I may ask, gentleman, please come back some other time, and it will help me a great deal. I swear, Timon is extremely upset. His cheerful disposition is gone, he is sick, and he keeps to his room.

dialogs.original: Many do keep their chambers are not sick:    And, if it be so far beyond his health,    Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts,    And make a clear way to the gods.
dialogs.translated: Lots of people who stay in their rooms aren't sick, and if he's as sick as you say he is, all the more reason for him to pay off his debts before he dies.

dialogs.original: Good gods!
dialogs.translated: Good lord!

dialogs.original: We cannot take this for answer, sir.
dialogs.translated: We can't accept this.

dialogs.original: [Within]  Servilius, help! My lord! my lord!
dialogs.translated: [Shouting from inside] Servilius, help! Timon! Timon!

dialogs.original: What, are my doors opposed against my passage?    Have I been ever free, and must my house    Be my retentive enemy, my gaol?    The place which I have feasted, does it now,    Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?
dialogs.translated: What, are my own doors going to shut themselves to me? Am I not free to leave my own house? Does the home to such great parties turn its back on me, like everyone else?

dialogs.original: Put in now, Titus.
dialogs.translated: Calm down Titus.

dialogs.original: My lord, here is my bill.
dialogs.translated: Here is the receipt for debts you owe me.

dialogs.original: Here's mine.
dialogs.translated: Here's mine.

dialogs.original: And mine, my lord.
dialogs.translated: And mine.

dialogs.original: And ours, my lord.
dialogs.translated: And ours.

dialogs.original: All our bills.
dialogs.translated: All our receipts.

dialogs.original: Knock me down with 'em: cleave me to the girdle.
dialogs.translated: Go ahead, kill me with them.

dialogs.original: Alas, my lord,-
dialogs.translated: But

dialogs.original: Cut my heart in sums.
dialogs.translated: Rip pieces of my heart out.

dialogs.original: Mine, fifty talents.
dialogs.translated: My receipt is for fifty talents.

dialogs.original: Tell out my blood.
dialogs.translated: Count my blood drop by drop and take it from me.

dialogs.original: Five thousand drops pays that.What yours?and yours?
dialogs.translated: Five thousand drops should cover.[To the other servants] What about all your receipts?

dialogs.original: My lord,
dialogs.translated: My lord

dialogs.original: My lord,
dialogs.translated: My lord

dialogs.original: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!
dialogs.translated: Tear me apart and take me away, and may the gods take their revenge upon you!

dialogs.original: 'Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their capsat their money: these debts may well be calleddesperate ones, for a madman owes 'em.
dialogs.translated: It seems our masters should probably give up on getting their money back. Now that Timon's mad, these debts are junk.

dialogs.original: They have e'en put my breath from me, the slaves.Creditors? devils!
dialogs.translated: [Panting] These men have even taken my breath away. They call themselves creditors? They are devils!

dialogs.original: My dear lord,
dialogs.translated: Timon

dialogs.original: What if it should be so?
dialogs.translated: [Coming up with an idea] But what if...

dialogs.original: My lord,
dialogs.translated: Timon

dialogs.original: I'll have it so. My steward!
dialogs.translated: [Realizing something] Yes, that's it! Come here!

dialogs.original: Here, my lord.
dialogs.translated: I'm here.

dialogs.original: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again,    Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius:    All, sirrah, all:    I'll once more feast the rascals.
dialogs.translated: So soon? Go get all those men for me. Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius, all of them! I'll throw them one last party!

dialogs.original: O my lord,    You only speak from your distracted soul;    There is not so much left, to furnish out    A moderate table.
dialogs.translated: But my lord you only speak in a daze. You do not have enough money yet to offer even a small meal.

dialogs.original: Be't not in thy care; go,I charge thee, invite them all: let in the tideOf knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide.
dialogs.translated: Don't worry about that. Go, and invite them all. Let in that wave of villains once more. My cook and I will figure it out.
